Asked about reported Guantánamo conditions, White House says migrants there are ‘criminals’ When asked Tuesday about inhumane conditions described by migrants held at Guantánamo Bay over the past two weeks, White House press secretary Karoline Leavitt told reporters not to forget that they were “criminals.” The Washington Post reported earlier Tuesday that migrants held at Guantánamo Bay had said they were allowed outside once a week for an hour, forced to use a bucket as a toilet, and shackled and placed in cells described as open-air cages. When asked about The Post’s reporting about the conditions migrants are facing at Guantánamo, Leavitt said, “It’s a promise the president campaigned on — that if you invade our nation’s borders, if you break our country’s laws, and if then you further commit heinous, brutal crimes in the interior of our country … then you are going to be deported from this country, and you may be held at Guantánamo Bay.” “These are criminals we are talking about,” she added. “Don’t forget that.” Silvia Foster-Frau and Ana Vanessa Herrero contributed to this report.
